NODE_TEXT:
All data are always exported when they are displayed in the current view without filter.

These functions are particularly beneficial if you want to edit large amounts of data. You do not need to open the individual charts with the CFC editor in order to edit the I/Os, as the I/Os of all charts in the hierarchy folders are imported automatically.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Configuring AS functions

# 8.7 Technological list editor

Further functions of the process object view include:

- Find/Replace
- Test mode
- Display data for fail-safe applications
- Split view with display in two windows (see above)
- View from WinCC Tag Logging for tabular configurtion of archive tags
- Defining user columns
- Undo

Always work in the process object view where possible. The overview provides considerable advantage in comparison to working in a CFC. The process object view also offers all the options of the plant hierarchy.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

# Configuring AS functions

# 8.8 Comparing projects with the Version Cross Manager (VXM)

# Functions

- Table-based engineering using CMTs
- Parameter assignment and interconnection of parameters of CMs
- Parameter assignment and interconnection of signals of CMs
- Parameter assignment of messages and alarms of CMs
- Export and import to/from Microsoft Excel
- Selective export to Excel using copy and paste
- Import to the list editor using copy and paste
- Identification of data inconsistencies during import

# Advantages

- Reduction of engineering errors
- MS Excel engineering requires no system-specific knowledge
- Export of CM-based engineering data without special tools – based on standard functions

# 8.8 Comparing projects with the Version Cross Manager (VXM)

The Version Cross Manager detects differences between the various revision levels (versions) of an engineering project. It can compare entire projects, hardware configurations, CFC/SFC charts, block types and instances, signals, run sequences, etc., with one another and thus detect any objects which are missing, which have been added, or which are different.

The import and export of project and planning data plus generation of process tags from CAx function charts are available as additional functions.

Note

The VXM process image is not updated during selective downloading of charts. An update is complete if all changed charts have been downloaded.

Usage scenarios and information on working with the Version Cross Manager can be found in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 Engineering System" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/109746533) manual.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# 8.9 Archiving/Versioning with Version Trail

The overall multiproject should be archived on a regular basis, with all projects and the master data library. If a number of changes are made during commissioning and FAT in the engineering stages, an archive/backup should be created every day. Archiving the relevant projects following each AS change download is recommended in production.

In addition to the easy archiving/retrieval via SIMATIC Manager there is also the option of versioning, creating and managing archives with the optional "Version Trail" package, although the archived data cannot be changed once this has been done. This means that defined archive versions can be compared with one another using the Version Cross Manager. You also have the option of setting up archiving in a time-controlled manner.

From PCS 7 V8.1 onwards, you have the option of automatic archiving after the successful downloading of the user program.

Note

A description of the process for archiving, including with the optional "Version Trail" package can be found in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 Engineering System" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/109746533) manual.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Compiling and downloading

# 9.1 Compiling the user program

The charts are reproduced in functions (FC) and data blocks (DB) when compiling the user program. The program is also checked for consistency, errors and warnings.

A1: The process object view offers an overview with considerable advantages over working in a CFC, including all the options of the plant hierarchy.
A2: Benefits include a comprehensive overview and access to all plant hierarchy options, surpassing the limitations of working within a CFC.
A3: Using the process object view provides significant advantages, such as an enhanced overview and full access to plant hierarchy functionalities, unlike the more restricted CFC environment.
A4: It allows for an extensive overview and utilizes all plant hierarchy features, offering more benefits than the confined space of a CFC.
A5: The view delivers a broad perspective and leverages every plant hierarchy option, presenting a superior alternative to the constraints of CFC work.

NODE_TEXT:
All data are always exported when they are displayed in the current view without filter.

These functions are particularly beneficial if you want to edit large amounts of data. You do not need to open the individual charts with the CFC editor in order to edit the I/Os, as the I/Os of all charts in the hierarchy folders are imported automatically.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

A5: Automatic archiving can be activated after downloading the user program successfully, a feature introduced in V8.1.

NODE_TEXT:
All data are always exported when they are displayed in the current view without filter.

These functions are particularly beneficial if you want to edit large amounts of data. You do not need to open the individual charts with the CFC editor in order to edit the I/Os, as the I/Os of all charts in the hierarchy folders are imported automatically.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Configuring AS functions

# 8.6 Managing process tag types with the process object view

Charts located in the selected hierarchy folder and all lower-level hierarchy folders are edited (in accordance with the selection made in the process object view).

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Configuring AS functions

# 8.7 Technological list editor

Further functions of the process object view include:

- Find/Replace
- Test mode
- Display data for fail-safe applications
- Split view with display in two windows (see above)
- View from WinCC Tag Logging for tabular configurtion of archive tags
- Defining user columns
- Undo

Always work in the process object view where possible. The overview provides considerable advantage in comparison to working in a CFC. The process object view also offers all the options of the plant hierarchy.

# 8.7 Technological list editor

# Introduction

The new technological list editor view is available starting in PCS 7 V9.0. The tabs of the technological list editor offer various displays, operator inputs and filter options for editing the technological types or objects along with their properties and attributes.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

199

# Configuring AS functions

# 8.8 Comparing projects with the Version Cross Manager (VXM)

# Functions

- Table-based engineering using CMTs
- Parameter assignment and interconnection of parameters of CMs
- Parameter assignment and interconnection of signals of CMs
- Parameter assignment of messages and alarms of CMs
- Export and import to/from Microsoft Excel
- Selective export to Excel using copy and paste
- Import to the list editor using copy and paste
- Identification of data inconsistencies during import

# Advantages

- Reduction of engineering errors
- MS Excel engineering requires no system-specific knowledge
- Export of CM-based engineering data without special tools – based on standard functions

# 8.8 Comparing projects with the Version Cross Manager (VXM)

The Version Cross Manager detects differences between the various revision levels (versions) of an engineering project. It can compare entire projects, hardware configurations, CFC/SFC charts, block types and instances, signals, run sequences, etc., with one another and thus detect any objects which are missing, which have been added, or which are different.

The import and export of project and planning data plus generation of process tags from CAx function charts are available as additional functions.

Note

The VXM process image is not updated during selective downloading of charts. An update is complete if all changed charts have been downloaded.

Usage scenarios and information on working with the Version Cross Manager can be found in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 Engineering System" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/109746533) manual.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# 8.9 Archiving/Versioning with Version Trail

The overall multiproject should be archived on a regular basis, with all projects and the master data library. If a number of changes are made during commissioning and FAT in the engineering stages, an archive/backup should be created every day. Archiving the relevant projects following each AS change download is recommended in production.

In addition to the easy archiving/retrieval via SIMATIC Manager there is also the option of versioning, creating and managing archives with the optional "Version Trail" package, although the archived data cannot be changed once this has been done. This means that defined archive versions can be compared with one another using the Version Cross Manager. You also have the option of setting up archiving in a time-controlled manner.

From PCS 7 V8.1 onwards, you have the option of automatic archiving after the successful downloading of the user program.

Note

A description of the process for archiving, including with the optional "Version Trail" package can be found in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 Engineering System" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/109746533) manual.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Compiling and downloading

# 9.1 Compiling the user program

The charts are reproduced in functions (FC) and data blocks (DB) when compiling the user program. The program is also checked for consistency, errors and warnings.
Q: What does compiling the user program entail according to the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Charts are reproduced in functions (FC) and data blocks (DB), and the program is checked for consistency, errors, and warnings.
A2: The process involves converting charts into FCs and DBs, alongside checking the program's consistency and for any errors or warnings.
A3: Compiling transforms charts into FCs and DBs while verifying the program's consistency and identifying errors or warnings.
A4: It includes the reproduction of charts in FCs and DBs and a thorough check for program consistency, errors, and warnings.
A5: During compilation, charts are turned into FCs and DBs, and the program undergoes a consistency check to spot errors and warnings.

NODE_TEXT:
All data are always exported when they are displayed in the current view without filter.

These functions are particularly beneficial if you want to edit large amounts of data. You do not need to open the individual charts with the CFC editor in order to edit the I/Os, as the I/Os of all charts in the hierarchy folders are imported automatically.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

Q: What is the purpose of the Version Trail package mentioned in the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: To enable versioning, creating, and managing archives without the possibility of changing the archived data.
A2: It allows for the creation and management of archive versions that can be compared, with the archived data remaining unalterable.
A3: The package facilitates versioning and archive management, ensuring archived data cannot be modified post-creation.
A4: Designed for versioning and managing archives, it prevents any alterations to the data once archived.
A5: Its role is to support versioning and archive management, locking the archived data against future changes.

Q: How can the Version Cross Manager be utilized according to the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: By comparing entire projects, hardware configurations, charts, block types and instances, signals, run sequences, etc., to detect differences.
A2: Utilized for comparing various project elements like hardware setups, charts, and signals to identify discrepancies.
A3: It's used to examine projects, hardware, charts, and more to find missing, added, or different objects.
A4: The manager compares projects, hardware, charts, among others, to spot any variations or anomalies.
A5: By analyzing projects, hardware configurations, charts, and other components to uncover any differences.
